conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the ball at the highest point P.
The ball starts with an initial upward velocity v0 = 4 m/s and reaches the highest point P.
Assuming no external forces other than gravity act on the ball.
The ball will be moving horizontally at the highest point because the vertical component of its motion is zero.
Using conservation of energy to find velocity at the highest point P.
Set up energy conservation equation: (1/2)mv0^2 = (1/2)mvP^2 + mgL.
Substitute values into the energy equation: (1/2)(1)(4)^2 = (1/2)(1)vP^2 + 1(10)(0.5).
Solve for vP: vP^2 = 6, vP = sqrt(6) m/s.
At the highest point P, the ball experiences gravitational force mg downward and force F exerted by the rod.
Net force in radial direction provides centripetal force: F - mg = mvP^2/L.
Substitute known values into the centripetal force equation: F - 10 = 6/0.5.
Solve for F: F - 10 = 12, F = 22 N.
Determine direction of force: F is radially inward towards the center of the circle.
Final answer: The magnitude of the force is 22 N, and the direction is radially inward.
